newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu dismisses talk of Meridor resignation.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu dismisses talk of Meridor resignation.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday dismissed speculation that Finance Minister Dan Meridor might resign.
Asked by reporters whether Meridor would continue as finance minister Netanyahu replied: "All those speculations...are not relevant. We are dealing with the problems themselves."
He added: "It is not on the agenda."
Israel's media has speculated in the past two days that Meridor could resign if Netanyahu decided to widen the shekel's trading bands.
While Bank of Israel Governor Jacob Frenkel has pushed for a widening of the bands Meridor said he fears this would cause an appreciation of the shekel, which could lead to a slowing of the economy.

Following an all-night meeting between the three that had forced Meridor to postpone a trip to the United States, Netanyahu said they had agreed on foreign currency reform and a budget cut. But talks on the shekel's bands were continuing, he said.
"I must deal with another two or three things but on this issue we'll continue work today and we'll complete it," Netanyahu said in remarks broadcast on Israel Radio after the meeting.
"I think that both the governor and the finance minister understand that great responsibility is on their shoulders but also in the end great responsibility is on my shoulders," he said.
